quotes.topic_title: Cold open: cultural erogenous zones concept
quotes.text: I often say to find your audience's cultural erogenous zones.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable framework for identifying what an audience already deeply cares about as the starting point for messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: cultural erogenous zones concept
quotes.text: So it's a huge lift to try to change someone's worldview or their passions. It's a light lift to take the thing you want to talk about and just shape it into, to fit into their worldview or their passions.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to adapt your message to existing audience motivations rather than trying to create new ones from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: cultural erogenous zones concept
quotes.text: There's going to be people who are just not your natural audience, and you should know that and not waste your time.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder to explicitly exclude non-fit audiences to focus effort where persuasion is realistically possible.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: cultural erogenous zones concept
quotes.text: But if your natural audience cares about X and you're offering Y, then it's your job to create the API or to create the bridge from X to Y.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Provides a concrete mental model—building an “API/bridge”—for translating what people care about into why they should care about your product.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: cultural erogenous zones concept
quotes.text: With messaging, it's not build it and they will come.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Challenges the common assumption that a strong product or story automatically attracts attention without deliberate audience-bridging.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I met Lulu while she was head of comms at Substack, where she was infamous for taking big risks and bold stands, and as a result creating a lot of attention for Substack, and other companies she's represented.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a cause-and-effect comms strategy: taking bold risks can generate outsized attention for an underdog brand.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation we get tactical about how to make your idea spread, cultural erogenous zones, the growing importance of going direct versus relying on traditional media.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a set of practical frameworks (idea spread, cultural erogenous zones, going direct) that practitioners can apply to communications strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The importance of taking risks in your comms and much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Emphasizes risk-taking as a core lever in communications, pushing against safer conventional PR playbooks.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What I love about AssemblyAI is you can use their simple API to access the latest AI breakthroughs from top tier research labs.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read
quotes.context: Highlights a practical build strategy: leverage a simple API to tap cutting-edge research without building models in-house.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They recently launched Conformer-1, the largest trained speech recognition model on the market which achieves state-of-the-art accuracy.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read
quotes.context: A concrete data point/example to benchmark vendor capability when evaluating speech-to-text solutions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Now you can move your cash into US treasuries with the flexibility of a bank account, and you can access your cash whenever you want even before your treasury bills hit maturity.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reframing that treasuries can be used with bank-like liquidity, changing how practitioners think about cash management.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: There are no hold periods, no settlement days, just a safe place to park your cash and earn a reliable yield.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read
quotes.context: Actionable operational detail about liquidity constraints (or lack thereof) that affects treasury/cash workflow decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Public will automatically reinvest your treasury bills at maturity, so you don't have to do anything to continue growing your yield.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor read
quotes.context: A simple automation “set-and-forget” methodology for maintaining yield without ongoing manual reinvestment.

quotes.topic_title: What makes ideas spread and stick
quotes.text: So there's a few ways to make the idea spread, the overall principle is you have to make it memorable and you have to make people want to say it of their own volition.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Defines the core two-part framework for spread: memorability plus intrinsic motivation to repeat.

quotes.topic_title: What makes ideas spread and stick
quotes.text: And so what doesn't make them want to say it is doing a favor for a corporation.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that corporate-benefit framing suppresses sharing because it feels like unpaid promotion.

quotes.topic_title: What makes ideas spread and stick
quotes.text: What does make them want to say it is they want to bring joy to somebody else, they want to make somebody laugh, they want to appear interesting, or they want to project some part of their identity.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Gives a practical checklist of share-motivations to design messaging around (joy, humor, status, identity).

quotes.topic_title: What makes ideas spread and stick
quotes.text: You can create a mental image that is very colorful.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Actionable tactic: engineer vivid imagery to increase recall and repeatability.

quotes.topic_title: What makes ideas spread and stick
quotes.text: But when I say put the pill in cheese, people tend to remember that and it's more easily repeatable.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Concrete example of a sticky metaphor that packages a message in a memorable, repeatable form.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: sticky phrases and memeable imagery
quotes.text: One example not for the better is binders of women.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A concrete example of how an unexpected phrase can capture attention—sometimes in unintended ways.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: sticky phrases and memeable imagery
quotes.text: You remember when Mitt Romney said binders of women and it just absolutely caught on like wildfire, and it's because you can picture the binder, it's a hilarious mental image.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism: vivid, funny mental imagery makes phrasing highly repeatable and shareable.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: sticky phrases and memeable imagery
quotes.text: It's a very specific unusual phrasing that is very repeatable, and it lends itself so much to memeing.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for crafting sticky language: specificity + unusual word order increases memetic spread.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: sticky phrases and memeable imagery
quotes.text: So it's not something that they wanted to have happen, which is a word of caution, this can backfire on you as well, but that's an example.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Highlights the counterintuitive risk that the same mechanics that drive virality can also amplify negative narratives.

quotes.topic_title: Examples: sticky phrases and memeable imagery
quotes.text: Those are these short phrases that take normal words and put them in an unusual order, and then especially if you repeat them a few times they just become very sticky.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A repeatable method: rearrange familiar words into an unusual structure and reinforce via repetition to create stickiness.

quotes.topic_title: How to craft a simple, repeatable tagline
quotes.text: You want to make it something that a second-grader could understand.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A simple bar for tagline clarity that forces you to remove complexity and jargon.

quotes.topic_title: How to craft a simple, repeatable tagline
quotes.text: You want to minimize the cognitive burden on the recipient.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A mental model for why taglines spread: reduce effort required to understand and remember them.

quotes.topic_title: How to craft a simple, repeatable tagline
quotes.text: So if you were to boil down the essence of let's say your company or your mission, get it to one sentence and then turn it into a sentence that you could explain to a second-grader, and then cleanse it of all cliches and common parlance.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A repeatable step-by-step process for crafting a tagline that’s clear and differentiated.

quotes.topic_title: How to craft a simple, repeatable tagline
quotes.text: And if you can then turn that into an analogy or if you can make it into something that has imagery, then you're probably 80, 90% of the way there.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A practical heuristic: imagery/analogy does most of the work in making a tagline memorable.

quotes.topic_title: A comms misstep: esoteric metaphor in a thread
quotes.text: I think it's useful to share my mistakes or missteps in addition to what went right, because there's more mistakes and missteps than what goes right.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A practical mindset for comms: systematically learning from what fails, not just what succeeds.

quotes.topic_title: A comms misstep: esoteric metaphor in a thread
quotes.text: In general, you try a bunch of things every once in a while they succeed.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A simple operating model for content/comms: expect low hit-rate and design for iteration.

quotes.topic_title: A comms misstep: esoteric metaphor in a thread
quotes.text: I think it was 30 something thousand likes among people that we cared about, people who write on the internet.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A concrete performance benchmark showing how far a thread can travel with the right audience.

quotes.topic_title: A comms misstep: esoteric metaphor in a thread
quotes.text: And I did the thing you're not supposed to do, which is take an inside joke with yourself and release it into the world.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A clear “don’t” for public writing: avoid context-less, insider references that confuse readers.

quotes.topic_title: A comms misstep: esoteric metaphor in a thread
quotes.text: And that one tweet was a dud in the middle of the thread where you could see the likes drop off precipitously and people were like, "What are you talking about?"
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A diagnostic signal practitioners can watch for: engagement drop-offs pinpoint confusing or off-message lines.

quotes.topic_title: Why comms should take calculated risks
quotes.text: I think if you're a startup your enemy is the status quo.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A crisp framing that clarifies what startups are really competing against and why comms needs to be proactive.

quotes.topic_title: Why comms should take calculated risks
quotes.text: And when you don't take risks, when you minimize risk by doing nothing, the best way to minimize risk is to do nothing. You're letting the status quo win.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that the “safest” comms choice can be strategically dangerous over time.

quotes.topic_title: Why comms should take calculated risks
quotes.text: And so I always encourage people to try to make mistakes of commission rather than omission.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A practical operating principle for choosing action and experimentation over inaction.

quotes.topic_title: Why comms should take calculated risks
quotes.text: Because if you make a mistake of commission you can observe it, you can learn from it.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Explains why visible failures are valuable: they create feedback loops that improve comms execution.

quotes.topic_title: Why comms should take calculated risks
quotes.text: So the example that I use, again, an analogy to make it more memorable, my analogy for this is if you are investing money in the market versus if you're just sitting in cash.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why avoiding volatility (risk) can quietly erode long-term outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Risk that worked: defending free expression stance
quotes.text: The stand for free speech thread would be a risk that worked out.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A concrete example of taking a controversial public stance that ultimately paid off.

quotes.topic_title: Risk that worked: defending free expression stance
quotes.text: It was a risk because it was a topic that a lot of people were already mad about, which will happen with every topic that matters.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing: backlash is a signal you’re engaging with something meaningful, not a reason to avoid it.

quotes.topic_title: Risk that worked: defending free expression stance
quotes.text: There was also the risk of you poke your head up and make a thing where there wasn't a thing, and if that were to go wrong and embarrass the company or if that had made Chris or Hamish or Jerraj upset, that would've been upsetting to me and obviously a failure of my job.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Highlights the often-overlooked execution and stakeholder-management risks of speaking publicly on sensitive issues.

quotes.topic_title: Risk that worked: defending free expression stance
quotes.text: I often say to find your audience's cultural erogenous zones, and it is something that you immediately know what I'm talking about.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A memorable framework for crafting messaging that instantly resonates with a specific audience’s values and sensitivities.

quotes.topic_title: Risk that worked: defending free expression stance
quotes.text: If I say know your audience's cultural erogenous zones, you know what it means, it's a shorthand that everybody understands.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Practical guidance for creating repeatable, sticky language that compresses a complex idea into an intuitive phrase.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: cultural erogenous zones framework
quotes.text: I often say to find your audience's cultural erogenous zones, and it is something that you immediately know what I'm talking about.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable shorthand framework for quickly anchoring messaging in what an audience already cares about.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: cultural erogenous zones framework
quotes.text: So what it means is people have things that they either care about or don't, and you're not going to change that.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Sets a realistic constraint for marketing: assume audience passions are fixed and work within them.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: cultural erogenous zones framework
quotes.text: It's a light lift to take the thing you want to talk about and just shape it into, to fit into their worldview or their passions.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to adapt your message to the audience’s existing worldview rather than trying to educate them from scratch.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: cultural erogenous zones framework
quotes.text: There's going to be people who are just not your natural audience, and you should know that and not waste your time.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Encourages deliberate audience selection and avoiding low-ROI persuasion attempts.

quotes.topic_title: Deep dive: cultural erogenous zones framework
quotes.text: But if your natural audience cares about X and you're offering Y, then it's your job to create the API or to create the bridge from X to Y.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Provides a concrete mental model (“API/bridge”) for connecting audience passions to product value in messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Example: reframing education as national security
quotes.text: And so she said the way to get their attention is you go to people who care about national security and you tell them, "Did you know that in order to enlist for the army you have to have a 10th grade reading level?"
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A concrete attention framework: connect your “unsexy” issue to what a target audience already cares deeply about.

quotes.topic_title: Example: reframing education as national security
quotes.text: If you can't read at that level, you're not going to be able to read the army field manual.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A vivid causal link that makes the argument feel real and urgent rather than abstract.

quotes.topic_title: Example: reframing education as national security
quotes.text: And so if you care about the future of national defense and being able to maintain a standing army, you need to care about middle grade reading standards.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Shows how to reframe a topic (education) as a prerequisite for a higher-stakes goal (national security).

quotes.topic_title: Example: reframing education as national security
quotes.text: So that's a perfect example, and in fact it stuck with me such that many years later I'm still repeating it to you.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Highlights the power of a sticky reframing: a good linkage gets remembered and repeated.

quotes.topic_title: Underdog playbook: build distribution and influencers
quotes.text: First, you have to acknowledge that you're the underdog, and you're not going to use the GE playbook from the 1980s or whatever.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Sets a contrarian premise: underdogs must reject incumbent-era playbooks and operate by different rules.

quotes.topic_title: Underdog playbook: build distribution and influencers
quotes.text: And so you should assume that you want to go with an approach that doesn't require a lot of money or people, that doesn't require that institutional backing and those relationships.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to choose strategies that are structurally compatible with startup constraints rather than resource-heavy tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Underdog playbook: build distribution and influencers
quotes.text: That means building your own distribution, which you can do starting from day one. You can start doing that before you even have the company.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A concrete, early-stage growth directive: invest in owned distribution immediately—even pre-company.

quotes.topic_title: Underdog playbook: build distribution and influencers
quotes.text: So you need to figure out who are the influencers and the way to do that, I'll cut off the rabbit hole after this because you can just go deeper and deeper, but the way to do that is in concentric circles.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable framework for identifying and activating influencers systematically rather than randomly.

quotes.topic_title: Underdog playbook: build distribution and influencers
quotes.text: So you need to get first really clear with yourself about what your message is and just get really crisp with it. This is hard to do because you know too much, so out of the 1,000 facts in your head you're going to have to pick just between one and three.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A practical messaging heuristic: compress complexity into 1–3 core facts before scaling distribution outward.

quotes.topic_title: Concentric circles: sequencing audiences for control
quotes.text: You've been telling people about recommendations for nearly a year. No one asked you to do that. We didn't pay you to do that. You've done it because you were brought on board early and it was something that the company made sure that you liked, and then you became the next circle out that spread it to your next circle out.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Concrete example of how early buy-in from power users turns them into organic evangelists who propagate updates outward.

quotes.topic_title: Concentric circles: sequencing audiences for control
quotes.text: If it had been like, "Hey, Lenny, can you do us a favor and tweet this thing?" You might've done it, but you would've done it once and stopped and it wouldn't have been something that you organically keep doing.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Contrasts one-off, transactional promotion with designing incentives that create sustained, voluntary sharing.

quotes.topic_title: Concentric circles: sequencing audiences for control
quotes.text: And the reason I say go out in concentric circles as opposed to just hit each of these groups kind of haphazardly is that's your way to control the message. Because each circle is going to assume that the inner circle knows better than them and they're going to follow the lead of the inner circle.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Defines the core mechanism of the concentric-circles framework: sequencing audiences to maintain message control via social proof.

quotes.topic_title: Concentric circles: sequencing audiences for control
quotes.text: And so that undermines everything that we're trying to do, you can't skip a circle is my point.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Memorable rule-of-thumb that warns practitioners not to bypass inner audiences (especially employees) when rolling out messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Concentric circles: sequencing audiences for control
quotes.text: If they feel like there's a bait and switch they're going to be really mad. And now you've created someone who is incredibly credible and has the same social and professional circle as you and is trying to ruin you.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Highlights the asymmetric downside risk of losing inner-circle believers—early insiders can become highly credible detractors.

quotes.topic_title: One-page doc: map audiences, zones, and channels
quotes.text: Yeah, you take out your one-page Google Doc. I feel like most comms problems can be solved with one-page Google Doc.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A memorable, simplifying principle: start with a single-page doc to clarify and solve communication strategy.

quotes.topic_title: One-page doc: map audiences, zones, and channels
quotes.text: So you go to your one-page Google Doc and you take your audiences, you list them, probably stop at five or six because past that it's like way, way first world problem.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Actionable scoping advice: constrain your audience list to a manageable 5–6 to avoid dilution and overwhelm.

quotes.topic_title: One-page doc: map audiences, zones, and channels
quotes.text: And you rank them by how much they're able to influence your success and how much credibility other groups assign them.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A concrete prioritization method: order audiences by impact on outcomes and perceived credibility to define inner/outer circles.

quotes.topic_title: One-page doc: map audiences, zones, and channels
quotes.text: And then for each of them you would think about what do they care about that's their cultural erogenous zones and where do they reside intellectually?
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A two-part audience mapping model: identify what emotionally motivates each group and the channels/communities where they consume ideas.

quotes.topic_title: One-page doc: map audiences, zones, and channels
quotes.text: But if we had just done that, nobody would've cared or maybe a few diehards would've cared.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A counterintuitive comms lesson: defending yourself directly often doesn’t move broader audiences unless tied to a bigger value they already care about.

quotes.topic_title: Comms equation: business goal to beliefs to channels
quotes.text: I think it's useful to try to bring as much discipline as possible to comms, because you're really just measuring vibes.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A crisp rationale for using structured frameworks in communications instead of relying on intuition.

quotes.topic_title: Comms equation: business goal to beliefs to channels
quotes.text: It assumes that you have a business goal and as a business goal, not communications goal, it's not get this many impressions or go viral or blah.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Reframes comms planning around business outcomes rather than vanity metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Comms equation: business goal to beliefs to channels
quotes.text: When you have your business goal you're going to need certain people to do certain things for that goal to come true.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Defines the next step in the comms “equation”: map outcomes to required actors and actions.

quotes.topic_title: Comms equation: business goal to beliefs to channels
quotes.text: The next step is what do they need to believe in order to take that action?
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Introduces the belief-layer as the key intermediate variable between messaging and behavior change.

quotes.topic_title: Comms equation: business goal to beliefs to channels
quotes.text: And that way you know that you're at least pushing forward and getting something done with your comms as opposed to just saying words into the ether.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Summarizes the practical payoff of the equation: comms becomes measurable progress toward action, not noise.

quotes.topic_title: Pressure = force/area: focus to increase impact
quotes.text: This is a useful one for early stage startups especially, or anybody who's just trying to be lean and efficient, which is anyone who's an underdog like we talked about earlier, that if you decrease the surface area than with the same amount of force you can apply more pressure. So the amount of pressure is the force divided by the surface area, this is a basic equation for physics, but it's also true of communications, which is if you decrease the surface area and don't try to appeal to everybody with everything.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A memorable physics-based framework for increasing communications impact by narrowing focus rather than increasing effort.

quotes.topic_title: Pressure = force/area: focus to increase impact
quotes.text: And you're targeting exactly whom you're talking to and you are sharpening your message to a point, to get them in the bullseye of the cultural erogenous zone. Then you're able to with the same amount of effort or expense or time, you're able to make more of an impact, you're able to apply more pressure.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on precision targeting and message sharpening to maximize impact with constrained resources.

quotes.topic_title: Pressure = force/area: focus to increase impact
quotes.text: So I think of it as there's a continuum between you can either hyper-target, so the extreme of the continuum is you are becoming the life partner of one person. That's the ultra hyper targeting. And then the other end of the spectrum is you're appealing to everybody. You're appealing to a larger number of people, but with a weaker message, in a weaker way.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A clear mental model for choosing between depth (hyper-targeting) and breadth (mass appeal) in go-to-market messaging.

quotes.topic_title: Pressure = force/area: focus to increase impact
quotes.text: So you have to choose where you're going to be along that continuum. And for most startups I would choose towards the fewer people end of it, where you choose who's going to be your diehards and then you foster them and create really deep meaningful relationships with them.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Practical advice to prioritize a small set of “diehards” and build deep relationships rather than chasing broad awareness early.

quotes.topic_title: Pressure = force/area: focus to increase impact
quotes.text: And I realized that the people that we were trying to speak to are heavy Twitter users, whether it's media people or online writers. And so I decided I'm going to spend some time and try to build an audience and then that audience became leverage, for better or worse.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A concrete example of matching channel strategy to where the target audience already is, and turning audience-building into leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: SOC 2 can either open the door for bigger and better deals or it can put your business on hold.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames SOC 2 as a high-leverage gatekeeper that directly affects revenue and deal velocity.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you don't have a SOC 2, there's a good chance you won't even get a seat at the table.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A blunt, memorable reminder that compliance can be a prerequisite for enterprise conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Over 3,000 fast growing companies use Vanta to automate up to 90% of the work involved with SOC 2.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption and efficiency data point to benchmark automation expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Vanta can get you ready for security audits in weeks instead of months, less than a third of the time that it usually takes.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Quantifies the potential time savings, turning compliance into a speed advantage rather than a drag.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Going back to this formula, pressure equals force divided by area.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a transferable mental model for increasing message effectiveness by manipulating “force” or “area.”

quotes.topic_title: Applying pressure framework: effort, credibility, ROI
quotes.text: It's the amount of effort you put into it. So it's how much you are spending on this campaign or you have a limited amount of hours in the day and dollars in the bank.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Defines “force” in the pressure framework as constrained resources (time and money) that can be deliberately allocated.

quotes.topic_title: Applying pressure framework: effort, credibility, ROI
quotes.text: Sometimes you're drawing down on credibility too, you have a certain amount of credibility and there are times when you just have to say, "Please trust me." You can spend that more efficiently if you focus.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Adds credibility as a spendable resource and argues focus increases the efficiency of that spend.

quotes.topic_title: Applying pressure framework: effort, credibility, ROI
quotes.text: So instead of if you just take a simple ad campaign, instead of spending a million dollars to reach a million people, maybe you spend a $100 to reach the hundred most important people.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, counterintuitive targeting example: concentrate small spend on the highest-leverage audience rather than broad reach.

quotes.topic_title: Applying pressure framework: effort, credibility, ROI
quotes.text: If you're just starting out, get 10 diehards and just spend all your time... You can't start out and try to win over the general public.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Actionable go-to-market advice for underdogs: prioritize a small base of true believers before scaling outward.

quotes.topic_title: Applying pressure framework: effort, credibility, ROI
quotes.text: But if you try to win over everybody at the same time, it's a food coloring in the ocean kind of thing as opposed to food coloring in a cup.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Memorable metaphor explaining why broad, unfocused messaging dilutes impact compared to dominating a small niche first.

quotes.topic_title: Niche first, then expand; Balaji example
quotes.text: If you're just starting out, get 10 diehards and just spend all your time... You can't start out and try to win over the general public. You start out by creating a tiny, not the best analogy is one I can think of right now, a tiny monopoly.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A concrete go-to-market starting point: win a very small group deeply before attempting broad appeal.

quotes.topic_title: Niche first, then expand; Balaji example
quotes.text: But if you try to win over everybody at the same time, it's a food coloring in the ocean kind of thing as opposed to food coloring in a cup.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why broad early targeting dilutes impact and makes traction hard to see.

quotes.topic_title: Niche first, then expand; Balaji example
quotes.text: He didn't try to compete with the roster of Harper Collins on their turf, and when he created his own distribution channels he focuses on who are the diehards and the truth fans, and these are people that he fosters.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A specific example (Balaji) showing how building your own distribution and nurturing true fans can outperform traditional channels.

quotes.topic_title: Niche first, then expand; Balaji example
quotes.text: There are people who just will never like that guy and he is totally fine with it. So he's not watering down who he is to appeal to people who will never like him, which it's tempting for companies to do.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Counterintuitive positioning advice: accept non-customers and avoid diluting your message to please everyone.

quotes.topic_title: Niche first, then expand; Balaji example
quotes.text: And you can't be remarkable if you're trying to appeal to so many people that you have to become the average of 500,000 people's tastes.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A crisp principle linking narrow focus to differentiation: broad appeal often forces blandness and invisibility.

quotes.topic_title: Why comms fails: too broad or too corporate
quotes.text: You're doing it as a corporation instead of a person.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A crisp diagnostic for why comms fails: audiences respond to humans, not institutional voice.

quotes.topic_title: Why comms fails: too broad or too corporate
quotes.text: And it doesn't work because people don't trust institutions. People don't like corporations or at least are not passionate about them. People care about people and trust and like people, and so there's a sense of wanting to cosplay an executive and it doesn't work, it doesn't resonate.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Explains the underlying mechanism—trust and emotional engagement—behind why corporate-speak underperforms.

quotes.topic_title: Why comms fails: too broad or too corporate
quotes.text: And then he became the human gateway drug for people to become interested in his company.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Memorable model for founder-led comms: the person is the entry point that pulls people into an otherwise “boring” category.

quotes.topic_title: Why comms fails: too broad or too corporate
quotes.text: But I think that for everybody a 100% of the time you want going direct to be a part of what you're doing, whether it's all you're doing, or whether you're doing something else, you can't not have a direct channel.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: always maintain an owned, direct-to-audience channel alongside any media strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Why comms fails: too broad or too corporate
quotes.text: It means that the founder or executive for some very senior person has to be speaking from themselves. First person, may be first person plural, and speaking in a human voice authentically. You see them make mistakes, you see them be vulnerable, and they have to become an ambassador to the community.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Concrete operational definition of “go direct” that practitioners can implement in voice, format, and behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Going direct: founder-led channels and picking one
quotes.text: But I think that for everybody a 100% of the time you want going direct to be a part of what you're doing, whether it's all you're doing, or whether you're doing something else, you can't not have a direct channel.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Establishes “go direct” as a non-optional pillar regardless of whether you also do traditional media.

quotes.topic_title: Going direct: founder-led channels and picking one
quotes.text: It means that the founder or executive for some very senior person has to be speaking from themselves. First person, may be first person plural, and speaking in a human voice authentically. You see them make mistakes, you see them be vulnerable, and they have to become an ambassador to the community.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Defines the operational requirements of a true direct channel: first-person, authentic, human, and community-anchored.

quotes.topic_title: Going direct: founder-led channels and picking one
quotes.text: To the point of focusing your energy and decreasing the surface area, for startups I would not recommend trying to do an Instagram, a Twitter, LinkedIn, YouTube, and TikTok. I would choose the thing that that person is the best at.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: A practical channel strategy: reduce surface area and pick one medium aligned with the founder’s strengths.

quotes.topic_title: Going direct: founder-led channels and picking one
quotes.text: So pick the thing that your spokesperson is the best at and then invest everything into that channel, and then build it up to a decent amount and then expand outward. Because if you try to build six or seven channels at once you're just not going to get anywhere.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Provides a sequencing methodology for founder-led distribution: focus deeply on one channel before expanding.

quotes.topic_title: Going direct: founder-led channels and picking one
quotes.text: Go with your gut pick one and you're not wed to that forever, you can always change it down the road.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Counters paralysis by emphasizing reversibility: start with one channel now and iterate later.

quotes.topic_title: Do founders need Twitter? Platform choice and LinkedIn
quotes.text: No, I think a lot of founders do. If they are super mission driven, for example, that's one way that you're going to find other people that resonate with your mission and that you're going to make the case for the mission.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Gives a practical criterion (mission-driven) for when Twitter is worth it as a founder.

quotes.topic_title: Do founders need Twitter? Platform choice and LinkedIn
quotes.text: If you're mission driven there's also a good chance that you're doing something that some people love and some people hate. And so you're going to need to be out there fighting the fight in a way. I don't mean in a pugilistic antagonistic way, but you have to defend your thing.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Highlights the need for public defense/advocacy when your company is polarizing, reframing social presence as mission defense.

quotes.topic_title: Do founders need Twitter? Platform choice and LinkedIn
quotes.text: I also think it's important if your charisma is a big part of recruiting for the company.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Offers a recruiting-driven heuristic for platform participation: founders should be visible when their personal magnetism is a hiring lever.

quotes.topic_title: Do founders need Twitter? Platform choice and LinkedIn
quotes.text: So Palmer Lucky and Anduril, he is magnetic to a lot of engineers and they want to go work with that guy, specifically.
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of founder charisma functioning as a recruiting engine.

quotes.topic_title: Do founders need Twitter? Platform choice and LinkedIn
quotes.text: LinkedIn is super underutilized because it gets a ton of eyeballs in time, but most of the content sucks. 95% of the content this is not scientific-
quotes.speaker: Lulu Cheng Meservey
quotes.context: Counterintuitive platform insight: LinkedIn’s low content quality creates an opportunity for founders to stand out.
